Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Power Generation from Fluid-Structure Interaction using Mathematical, Computational and Experimental Modeling

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merits: The interaction of a flowing fluid and a deformable structure or solid is one of the richest sources of mathematical challenges and fundamental physical phenomena with important applications to engineering and technology including energy harvesting and power generation. The physical phenomena of interest range from blood flows in arteries, to airflow over an oscillating tongue that can lead to clinical dangerous and potentially fatal oscillations, to flow over flexible long span bridges and tall buildings, to flow over and around flight vehicles over a wide range of scales from micro air vehicles to modern passenger airliners, to fluid-structural systems whose limit cycles may be a source of energy harvesting and power generation. It is this last application that motivates much of the proposed work. While in many applications the concern is that the limit cycle oscillations will damage the mechanical integrity of the fluid/structural system, in the energy harvesting and power generation application these oscillations will be both novel and beneficial.
The methods that have been proposed to better understand and exploit these phenomena include theoretical models of high sophistication including the continuum models of the fluid and the structure. While analytical solutions continue to be sought and found, computational models that tax the resources of the most powerful computers also play an important role, as do scale model experiments based upon a sound fundamental analysis and understanding of the first principles of the relevant continuum models. Indeed, it is by exploiting the complementary strengths of each approach theoretical modeling, computational modeling, and experimental scale models that the deepest and richest insights can be obtained.

Broader Impact: This proposal brings together senior investigators from three major research institutions covering a wide range of intellectual experience from modern mathematics to rigorously based computational models to multidisciplinary experiments to address fluid-structure interaction phenomena. This research will also provide an opportunity for graduate students and post-doctoral visitors to participate and learn in this rich environment.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Goals:

The main idea for the project was as follows: Prior fluid-structure interaction studies have shown that slender beams and thin plates along which air flows have the potential to experience sustained and self-excited oscillations, which can be used to harvest energy. Embedded piezoelectric materials have long been known to be capable of actuating suitably designed structures, as well as of converting structural strain into electrical energy.

In order to pursue the potential benefits of these mechanisms, a collaborative research program among Duke, UCLA, and Georgia Tech was established with funding from NSF. The approach of the Georgia Tech team is fourfold:

(1) Develop a 1-D beam theory for beams made of active materials based on the work of Yu et al. [1–3] as implemented in the beam cross-sectional analysis code VABS. This portion of the work was successfully completed.

(2) Update the open-source computer code GEBT (Geometrically Exact Beam Theory) with new terms in this beam theory that stem from piezoelectric materials. This portion of the work was also successfully completed.

(3) Develop a low-order aerodynamics code similar to the one developed by our colleagues at Duke University and couple it with the revised version of GEBT. The code GESBT (with the S representing “Smart”) was developed, but unexpected challenges arose during attempts to validate it.

(4) Apply this new analysis to energy harvesting via various means. This portion could not be successfully completed because we were unable to validate the code developed in #3.

Approach and Accomplishments

The project began in September 2013. The funding for Georgia Tech was $108,000 over three years, which is $36,000 per year. The grant lacked sufficient funding to support a graduate research assistant. Realizing this, the PI focused on developing a team that was funded mostly by sources other than NSF. These researchers helped to accomplish the tasks associated with the work.

Prof. Peng Li of Southwest Jiaotong University in Chengdu, China, obtained a fellowship from the Chinese government to visit Georgia Tech for one year and was chosen by the PI to work on this project.

Mr. Mann Kyo “Lance” Cho was a self-supporting MS student who worked with Prof. Li on the aerodynamic modeling. The PI and Prof. Li worked with Cho in developing to develop an unsteady aerodynamics analysis based on potential flow theory to be coupled with GEBT (an open-source code available from Purdue University).

Validation of the code was addressed by Mr. Bruno Henrique Da Silveira, a summer intern from Brazil. Unfortunately, he discovered that it produced erroneous results for certain cases, which were not obtained until months after Cho had ended his graduate studies and taken a job elsewhere. Da Silveira worked several weeks to uncover the reasons for these erroneous results. Results obtained for moderately thick plates were reasonable. However, it turned out that the bending stiffnesses of the plates studied in Prof. Li’s work were very small and gave rise to modal damping results that did not vary with air speed (which is physically incorrect). Reasons behind these unexpected incorrect results are still not understood.

Mr. Chirag Sachdeva was a guest researcher from India on a summer internship during summer 2016. Working with the PI, Chirag was able to successfully develop the theory for incorporating VABS results for smart materials, successfully incorporate it into GEBT, and successfully validate the resulting computer code. A paper is in preparation and is planned for submission to a journal this fall. 

Two test cases are presented in the figures. The data are givem in the first figure, and the results showing excellent agreement between the beam theory and a 3-D finite element solution are in the second. 

Finally, in addition to all this, the Georgia Tech team collaborated with Dr. Pezhman Mardanpour, starting when he was a postdoctoral fellow on the UCLA team with Prof. Balakrishnan (deceased) resulting in several journal papers and a book chapter.
